content:
- 18 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
As a result, the Salmonella Reference Laboratory is identifying strains from human infections, animal diseases (including poultry), and from various foodstuffs.
The cultures are investigated both as to their biochemical reactions and their antigenic structure. Reports are sent back to the laboratory, and are therefore couched in scientific terms, giving details of antigenic structure and any bio- chemical or other results which are worthy of comment.
*Cultures which, on investigation, are not salmonellae, have a full report giving all the biochemical and serological reactions found, together with the interpretation of these findings. This method of reporting has been a most valuable means of disseminating technical knowledge in an informal way.
The Standards Laboratory, which issues reagents for salmonella identification, has been in existence since 1917. Occasionally special sera are issued. Normally type strains are issued by the National Collection of Type Cultures, but special cultures are occasionally issued by the Salmonella Reference Laboratory. The Salmonella Reference Laboratory investigates the sera of man and animals for the presence of salmonella agglutinins. This is done very rarely and only in special circumstances.
許躍爾
The full identification of , 140 112 26 382.11a is made, and the results new serotypes of salmonella reported in the press. But before publication, cultures are sent to the Inter- national Salmonella and Escherichia Centre at Copenhagen, and to the Communicable Disease Centre, Atlanta, for checking.
The Salmonella Reference Laboratory works in close liaison with the Epidemio- logical Research Laboratory at Colindale. Hospital and Public Health Laboratories throughout England and Wales report all cases and outbreaks of salmonella infection each week to the epidemiological unit, Colindale, which circulates this information, together with other information, to all laboratories. Final reports on outbreaks are sent to the Salmonella Reference Laboratory. When all the information is available this material is sorted and returned to the epidemiological unit for inclusion in the annual report on food poisoning and salmonella infections.
As the Salmonella Reference Laboratory is in close touch with the veterinary and food laboratories, it is sometimes possible to advise on suitable investigations
國史饭 Academia Historica
90

As a result, the Salmonella Reference Laboratory is identifying strains from human infections, animal diseases (including poultry), and from various foodstuffs.

The cultures are investigated both as to their biochemical reactions and their antigenic structure. Reports are sent back to the laboratory, and are therefore couched in scientific terms, giving details of antigenic structure and any bio- chemical or other results which are worthy of comment.

*Cultures which, on investigation, are not salmonellae, have a full report giving all the biochemical and serological reactions found, together with the interpretation of these findings. This method of reporting has been a most valuable means of disseminating technical knowledge in an informal way.

The Standards Laboratory, which issues reagents for salmonella identification, has been in existence since 1917. Occasionally special sera are issued. The Salmonella Reference Laboratory investigates the sera of man and animals for the presence of salmonella agglutinins. This is done very rarely and only in special circumstances.

The full identification of , 140 112 26 382.11a is made, and the results new serotypes of salmonella reported in the press. The Salmonella Reference Laboratory works in close liaison with the Epidemio- logical Research Laboratory at Colindale. Hospital and Public Health Laboratories throughout England and Wales report all cases and outbreaks of salmonella infection each week to the epidemiological unit, Colindale, which circulates this information, together with other information, to all laboratories.
